entry.title: What's new for Production Planning in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud 2025
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud has been officially released, and many new feature were delivered for production planning. From UI improvements to the MRP Cockpit Fiori apps to new Business Add-Ins available for MRP and production orders, this blog provides an overview of those new features that are available in the latest SAP S/4HANA release.

Improvements for MRP Cockpit Fiori Apps

Several improvements were delivered for the MRP Cockpit Fiori Apps Monitor Material Coverage - Net Segments (F0247A), Monitor Material Coverage - Net and Individual Segments (F2101A) and Manage Material Coverage (F0251A), bringing additional functionalities that util now were only available in the Stock/Requirements List, and also innovations that will mimic features originally available in the MRP List. 

Rescheduling and Cancelling of Proposals

Fiori Apps Monitor Material Coverage - Net Segments (F0247A) and Monitor Material Coverage - Net and Individual Segments (F2101A) were enhanced to display information about the number of rescheduling proposals that were generated for a specific material.

These apps will now display of the number of rescheduling proposals, and new filters were also introduced to allow users to filter for materials with specific rescheduling messages. The following figure shows the new fields and the new filters in the app Monitor Material Coverage.


Figure 1: Rescheduling Proposals in Monitor Material Coverage

Fiori app Manage Material Coverage has been also enhanced with new actions that will help users to resolve coverage issues and make sure requirements can be met as planned:

  • Proposals to reschedule MRP elements to an earlier date (reschedule in)
  • Proposals to reschedule MRP elements to a later date (reschedule out)
  • Proposals to cancel MRP elements (cancel process)

The following figure shows and example of the action Reschedule Out, for a purchase order with a rescheduling message:


Figure 2: Rescheduling actions in Manage Material Coverage

 

Last MRP Run

Fiori Apps Monitor Material Coverage and Manage Material Coverage were also enhanced to show the date of the last MRP Run, and to allow users to filter for material segments using the date of the Last MRP Run. The following figures show the filter and the field in Monitor Material Coverage and Manage Material Coverage.


Figure 3: Last MRP Run in Monitor Material Coverage

 

Figure 4: Last MRP Run in Manage Material Coverage

 

Planning Time Fence and Manual Firming Date

Another enhancement to the Monitor Material Coverage and Manage Material Coverage Fiori apps was the introduction of the Planning Time Fence and the possibility to set or change a Manual Time Fence.

New filters and columns for MRP type and planning time fence were added into the Material Coverage app, as we can see in the Figure below.


Figure 5: Planning Time Fence and MRP Type in Monitor Material Coverage

 

As we can see in Figure 6, Fiori App Manage Material Coverage now can show the Planning Time Fence, and users will also have the possibility to edit the Planning Time Fence.  

Figure 6: Planning Time Fence in Manage Material Coverage


Accept MRP Run Result

SAP S/4HANA 2025 also introduced a new feature called Accept the MRP results, allowing the planner to mark materials for which the MRP result has been already evaluated.

A new filter has been already introduced in Fiori App Monitor Material Coverage, so that the planner can filter for material segments where the MRP result has been already accepted or not, and there is also a new column called MRP Result Accepted, as we can see in Figure 7.

Figure 7: MRP Result Accepted in Fiori App Monitor Material Coverage

 

Fiori app Manage Material Coverage has also been enhanced with a button that allows the planner to Accept the MRP Results, or revoke the Acceptance of MRP results, as shown in Figure 8.  

Figure 8: Button Accept MRP Result in Fiori App Manage Material Coverage

 

This feature has been also introduced in both collect and individual access of the Stock/Requirements List (transactions MD04 and MD07), as I described in my blog Accept/Revoke MRP Run results in the Stock/Requirements List and MRP Fiori Apps, and it is available for earlier releases, as described in the blog. However, only as of SAP S/4HANA 2025 users will have the ability to mass Accept and Revoke the MRP Results from the Collective Access of the Stock/Requirements List, as shown in Figure 9.


Figure 9: Mass acceptance of MRP results in the Stock/Requirements List.

 

Downporting new features to SAP S/4HANA 2023

Some of the new features listed above can be also introduce in SAP S/4HANA 2023 with the implementation of the following notes:

No.

SAP Note

Description

1

3586336

SAP- Production Planning- Supporting Features- Rescheduling Proposals, Planning time fence and Last MRP Run.

2

3592002

SAP- Production Planning- Rescheduling Proposals, Planning time fence and Last MRP Run in Monitor material coverage- Net & Individual segments Fiori Application ( F2101A )

3

3592003

SAP- Production Planning- Rescheduling Proposals, Planning time fence and Last MRP Run in Monitor material coverage- Net segments ( F0247A )

4

3591572

SAP- Production Planning- Rescheduling Proposals, Planning time fence and Last MRP Run in Manage material coverage Fiori Application (F0251A)

 

MRP Live 

Technical improvements were also delivered for MRP Live in SAP S/4HANA 2025, including new BAdIs and the improvements in the integration of documents with PP/DS and IBP.

Business Transaction Events in MRP Live

SAP S/4HANA introduced a new feature in MRP Live, that allows the creation of business transaction events (BTEs) for business documents created within MRP Live (e.g. planned orders, purchase requisitions, scheduling agreements and stock transfer requisitions) enabling post-processing steps for other applications like PP/DS, IBP.

In previous releases, materials for which documents had to be integrated to PP/DS or IBP had to be planned by MRP Live in ABAP instead of HANA, because documents generated or changed by MRP were integrated by means of an RFC. With the new integration using BTE events, those materials can be planned in HANA, which an improved MRP Live performance.

For example, if we activate Advanced Planning for a material, and we choose the option PP/DS Display Only for the scope limitation, this material would be planned in ABAP by MRP Live. As of SAP S/4HANA 2025, we can use BTE events to integrate those documents, allowing the material to be planned in HANA.

The setting to activate the integration with BTE can be found in transaction PPHMRPSET, as we can see in Figure 10.


Figure 10: Setting to activate Business Transaction Events in MRP Live.

New BAdIs for MRP

  • Adjustment of Planned Order Component Data during BOM Explosion (PPH_PLDORD_COMP_ADJ):  This new BAdI allows you to modify the storage location and production supply area of components in planned orders during BOM explosion in the following processes:

    • Planning run of material requirements planning and master production scheduling

    • Manual planned order creation
    • Backflush for repetitive manufacturing without planned order

  • Additional Parameters for Navigation Profile (MD_NAVIGATION_ADJUSTðŸ˜ž With this new BAdI you can change the parameter IDs for transactions which are maintained in Customizing activity Define Navigation Profiles. Navigation profiles enable you to navigate faster and more flexibly between transactions, and with the new BAdI you can use more than only three parameter IDs.

 

Shop-Floor Control

Besides the already mentioned improvements for MRP, SAP S/4HANA 2025 also brought improvements for Shop-Floor Control, including a better handling for partial consumption posted from EWM, and new technical objects, like RAP Business Objects and Data Products. 

 

Partial Consumption and Split for Error Handling for Automatic Goods Movement, COGI

SAP S/4HANA 2025 also introduced a new feature that enables partial retrograde goods issue for non-batched and non-serialized components in embedded SAP Extended Warehouse Management, checking availability in the bin of the production supply area during the manufacturing process

This feature allows postprocessing of error records from automatic goods movements (COGI transaction) only for unavailable quantities of components, and it works for discrete and repetitive manufacturing. It will enable as-is partial goods movement between SAP EWM and production during synchronous goods movement processes, increasing PSA stock control, reducing clerical work, and improving accuracy of stock data. Figure 11 shows the setting use to activate this new feature in the Production Scheduling Profile.


Figure 11: Goods Issue Quantity Split setting in the Production Scheduling Profile

 

Example:

  • 3 EA of component KOMPK1-01 are available in the bin in production supply area, as shown in Figure 12.


Figure 12: 3 EA of component available in the Supply Area.

 

  • Figure 13 shows that the backflush of the component for a production order requires 12 EA,


Figure 13: Backflush requires 12 EA of the component.

 

  • When we post the backflush for the production order, 3 EA of component KOMPK1-01 are issued, as shown in Figure 14.


Figure 14: Backflush was posted and the consumption of 3 EA has been posted.

 

  • As we have activated the Goods Issue Quantity Split in the Production Scheduling Profile, the remaining quantity of 9 EA went into Postprocessing of Error Records from Automatic Goods Movements (transaction COGI), as shown in Figure 15.

 


Figure 15: Postprocessing of the remaining quantity in COGI

 

BAdI for Initialization of Order Component on Creation

With the new Business Add-In (BAdI), Order Component - Initialization on Creation (PPH_PRODORD_COMP_ADJ) you can fill the material planning relevance and the bulk indicator at the order component (reservation) level when creating an order.

 

RAP Business Objects for Production Orders

SAP S/4HANA 2025 also brought new technical objects that will help customers to make sure that custom developments are clean core compatible. New RAP Business Objects were introduced for Production Orders, Process Orders and Routings, enabling cloud-native APIs for SAP BusinessObjects in production execution and on-stack extensibility for Manufacturing.



Figure 16: New Production and Process Order RAP BOs 

 

Manufacturing Data Products

A SAP data product is a pre-packaged dataset that is ready for consumption by applications for analytics, AI, and other business intelligence purposes. A comprehensive set of ERP data products sourced from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition is now available, providing structured insights into manufacturing execution:

  • Production version
  • Work center
  • Manufacturing codes
  • Production confirmation
  • Production order
  • Enterprise resource capacity
  • Production routing]

SAP API Hub provides more information about the Manufacturing Data Products.

 

See also:

Planning Time Fence and Last MRP Run

Accept Planning Result of MRP Run

Rescheduling Proposals for MRP Elements

Business Transaction Events in MRP Live

BAdI for Adjustment of Planned Order Component Data during BOM Explosion

BAdI for Allowing Additional Parameters for Navigation Profile

BAdI for Initialization of Order Component on Creation

Partial Goods Issue for Component Consumption in Manufacturing

API Hub

 

Brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA Regional Implementation Group

entry.title: FTFY: S/4HANA 2025 should be S/4HANA 2026
entry.content:
We need to fix the S/4HANA version names

S/4HANA carries the version of the year it was released

The problem is, new S/4HANA versions are always released in October/November and carry that year as the version

For example S/4HANA 2025 was released in October 2025

Even the fastest S/4HANA Customers would struggle to get this in to Production before 2026

And that's the problem

The Customer goes live in 2026 with the latest version of S/4HANA....  S/4HANA 2025

And cosmetically if just looks wrong and causes confusion ðŸ˜ž

It looks old before it's even been implemented in Production !

SAP should follow the lead of car manufacturers with the Model Year concept

 
<This part was written by Google AI - AI Overview>
  • Model year (MY): This refers to the model cycle and the specific set of features, trims, and updates for a particular vehicle. For example, a car manufactured in late 2024 could be designated as a 2025 model year (MY2025) because it features the new upgrades for that year

</This part was written by Google AI - AI Overview>

Following this approach, S/4HANA 2025 would be called S/4HANA 2026

And all Customers deploying S/4HANA 2026 during the calendar year 2026 would be able to say to their "Business" that they are rolling out the latest version of S/4HANA which is called S/4HANA 2026

That's it

What do you think ?

Andy.

entry.title: Handling Record Count Mismatches After HANA Tenant Copy During S/4HANA On-Premise to RISE Migration
entry.content:
As part of a system move, We performed a HANA tenant copy from our on-premise S/4HANA system to the RISE environment. After completing the tenant copy, we compared the total record count of the SAPABAP1 schema using:

SELECT SUM(RECORD_COUNT) FROM M_TABLES WHERE SCHEMA_NAME = 'SAPABAP1';

Source Record count:

Target Record count:

A small difference appeared between the source and the target system.
To validate the result, We first checked whether any column-store tables were unloaded using:

SELECT SCHEMA_NAME, TABLE_NAME FROM M_CS_TABLES WHERE LOADED = 'NO';

No unloaded tables were found, so the values from M_TABLES were correct for comparison.

To investigate the difference, I exported and compared the table-level record counts.

The mismatch came from the following tables:

Table Name

Source

Target

/BI0/0K00193590

1

0

/BI0/0K00193626

2

0

/BI0/0K00193632

2

0

/BI0/0K00193575

1

0

All of these objects belong to the /BI0/ namespace.

Information provided by SAP clarifies that these objects are temporary BW tables, as described in SAP Note 2800007.
They are created during BW processing and are not persistent. So we took the confirmation and ignored these tables as they are temporary tables.

Additional related details include:

  • Hash / union temporary tables (40-character names)
    These store intermediate results for hierarchy queries. They are copies of 0BW:BIA:BI0* objects with a retention time. Unneeded tables are removed using BW cleanup tools such as:
    • Report SAP_DROP_TMPTABLES
    • Function module TREX_DBS_DROP_BW_UNION_TABLES
      Notes 2838176 and 2852066 describe adjustments and cleanup behaviour.
  • Temporary tables in the pattern 0BW:BIA:BI0*
    These hold temporary hierarchy or F4 help data. They are cleaned automatically or through report RSDDTMPTAB_DELETE.
    SAP Note 3316894 describes a case where automatic cleanup may not run as expected.

According to this information, differences in these temporary table counts between systems are normal and depend on BW usage and cleanup cycles.

An important point :- it's necessary to exercise maximum caution before dropping these tables. Consultation with a BW consultant is advised.

Conclusion: 

The record count mismatch observed after the HANA tenant copy was limited to BW temporary tables described in SAP Note 2800007. These tables are not persistent and may exist or be cleaned up at different times in different systems. Because of this, small differences in their record counts are expected and do not indicate any issue with the tenant copy. The overall tenant copy can be considered consistent and successfully completed.

entry.title: Slaying the S/4 HANA Dual Maintenance & interim State Monster: Palantir's Trick to Treat Your Budget
entry.content:
INTRODUCTION

Imagine trying to rebuild your entire house, from the foundations up, while still living in it and running your daily life! That's the scale of the challenge many global enterprises are embracing as they transition from SAP ECC to S/4HANA. It's not just a tech upgrade; it's arguably the most significant transformation they'll undertake this decade.

Given the sheer size, the intricate sap integration web of operations with other systems, and all those unique regional needs, no one wants to risk bringing their business to a standstill. That's why most organisations are wisely choosing a thoughtful, multi-year, phased rollout.

Migrating from SAP ECC to S/4HANA is one of the most significant transformations many global enterprises will undertake this decade. Given the scale, complexity, and regional dependencies involved, most organizations opt for a multi-year, phased rollout to minimize business disruption.

While this approach minimizes business disruption, it introduces a costly challenge: dual maintenance the need to maintain, reconcile, and synchronize data and processes across both ECC and S/4 systems during the transition period.

In this post, weâ€™ll explore how Palantirâ€™s data integration and digital twin capabilities can dramatically reduce those interim costs, streamline operations, and accelerate time-to-value.

The Dual Maintenance Dilemma

During a staggered rollout, some business units run on ECC while others move to S/4HANA. This creates temporary but expensive complexity:

  • Duplicate data maintenance across ECC and S/4 systems (e.g., master data, pricing conditions, bills of material)

  • Parallel reporting landscapes, as analytics must draw from both systems

  • Integration bridges required to maintain end-to-end process continuity (order-to-cash, procure-to-pay, etc.)

  • Reconciliation overhead to ensure financial and operational consistency

These efforts can add millions in IT and business costs annually during the rollout.

What Palantir does differently for Interim State?

Rapid Data Integration: Foundry excels at ingesting and integrating vast amounts of disparate data (structured, unstructured, streaming) from various source systems (legacy databases, cloud applications, IoT devices, spreadsheets, etc.) into a single, coherent data asset. This significantly reduces the need for manual data manipulation or temporary data warehouses.

Dynamic Data Models (Ontology): Instead of static data models, Foundry builds a dynamic "ontology" , a living, interconnected representation of an organisation's real-world entities (e.g., customers, assets, products, events) and their relationships. This provides a unified, real-time "digital twin" of the organisation's operations. This eliminates the "interim state" of fragmented data views and manual reconciliation.

Data Lineage and Governance: Foundry automatically tracks data lineage, providing transparency on where data comes from and how it's transformed. This builds trust in the data and reduces the need for manual validation steps often found in interim processes.

Accelerated Application Development: Users can build operational applications, dashboards, and analytical tools directly on top of this integrated ontology without needing to move data to separate systems. This bypasses the need for bespoke, temporary solutions that often characterise an interim state.

System of Engagement over System of Record": Palantir often acts as a "system of engagement" or "system of analysis" that sits on top of existing "systems of record." It doesn't require organisations to immediately rip and replace their legacy systems. Instead, it integrates data from these systems, allowing them to continue functioning while providing a modern, unified operational layer.

In essence, Palantir Foundry's unique value lies in its ability to rapidly integrate and harmonise data from across an enterprise into a dynamic, operational ontology. This provides a single, coherent source of truth and a platform for building applications, thereby eliminating the need for costly "interim states" and allowing organisations to strategically reduce or retire redundant systems, thus cutting "dual maintenance running costs".

Palantir: A Unified Data and Process Layer

Palantir Foundry offers a powerful solution: instead of forcing every application, report, and integration to connect separately to ECC and S/4HANA, organizations can use Palantir as a single harmonized data layer across both systems.

This creates a â€œdigital twinâ€ of the enterprise that abstracts away the differences between ECC and S/4, providing unified access to operational and analytical data without redundant maintenance.

How Palantir Helps Reduce Interim Dual Maintenance Costs

1. Unified Data Model for ECC and S/4

Palantir can connect directly to both ECC and S/4HANA systems (via SAP connectors, OData services, or data extracts) and harmonize the key master and transactional data - customers, materials, vendors, G/L accounts into a single, consistent data model.

Example: Instead of maintaining customer hierarchies in both ECC and S/4, Palantir can ingest them from ECC and apply transformation logic that reflects the new S/4 model. Downstream systems (analytics, planning, compliance) can consume the Palantir layer directly, avoiding the need to replicate changes twice.

Impact: Reduces data duplication and manual harmonization efforts by up to 60â€“70% during migration.

2. Process Continuity Through Digital Twins

Palantirâ€™s Operational Data Layer (ODL) enables enterprises to create a digital twin of critical business processes  such as order-to-cash or supply chain flows  across ECC and S/4 boundaries.

Example: Imagine a company where Europe has migrated to S/4 but North America is still on ECC. Orders may flow from ECC customers to S/4 production plants. Instead of building and maintaining multiple custom SAP interfaces, Palantir can serve as the process bridge â€” integrating order, inventory, and delivery data in real-time to ensure seamless visibility and coordination.

Impact: Cuts custom integration and reconciliation costs while ensuring consistent KPIs across regions.

3. Harmonized Analytics Layer

Reporting is one of the biggest pain points during phased migration. Palantir provides a centralized analytics layer where ECC and S/4 data can be combined, transformed, and visualized using the same semantic logic.

Example: Finance teams can view a consolidated P&L across both systems without reconciling chart of accounts manually. Palantirâ€™s ontology layer standardizes financial attributes (cost centers, profit centers, etc.) across systems, enabling consistent reporting months  or years  before full migration completes.

Impact: Eliminates need for maintaining dual SAP BW or SAC models during rollout.

4. Accelerated Master Data Migration

By connecting to both source (ECC) and target (S/4) systems, Palantir can simulate and validate master data transformations in advance. This reduces rework during each migration wave.

Example: For materials management, Palantir can pre-map ECC material master attributes to S/4â€™s simplified data model, identify inconsistencies, and validate against business rules all without touching production systems.

Impact: Reduces downtime and errors during each cutover, saving time and resources.

5. Continuous Value Delivery During Transition

Palantirâ€™s modular architecture allows business users to build analytics and decision applications that remain valid even after the migration is complete. This protects investments in data products and dashboards, reducing re-implementation costs post-S/4 go-live.

Illustrative Scenario: A Global Manufacturing Company

Context: A global manufacturer is migrating from ECC to S/4HANA over 4 years. Europe goes live first, while APAC and North America remain on ECC.

Challenges:

  • Global financial consolidation required across mixed systems

  • Duplicate master data maintenance in multiple systems

  • Integration pain for global supply chain visibility

Palantir Solution:

  • Build a unified Palantir data model integrating ECC and S/4 data

  • Create operational dashboards for global supply chain using this harmonized data

  • Maintain a single master data governance workflow through Palantirâ€™s ontology layer

Outcome:

  • 50% reduction in IT maintenance costs during rollout

  • Single version of truth for finance and operations

  • Seamless reporting continuity across systems

In essence, Palantir allows you to â€œrun as oneâ€ even while youâ€™re still migrating to one.

#SAP #S4HANA, #Palantir, #DigitalTransformation, #CloudTransformation, #DualMaintenance, #SAPMigration, #EnterpriseMigration, #ERPStrategy, #BusinessTransformation #ERPTraansformation

entry.title: SAP Ariba SLP - MDG attachment Integration - Making the Impossible Possible
entry.content:
The integration between SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance (SLP) and SAP Master Data Governance for Suppliers (MDG-S) enables extensive synchronization of supplier master data across both systems through choreographed business scenarios. The SLP-MDG integration supports bidirectional data exchange between SAP Ariba SLP and MDG-S, ensuring consistent supplier master data across both applications. If you would like to know the supported scenarios within this integration, refer to the standard documentation here

In this section, we will cover the details of integrating attachments from Ariba SLP into SAP MDG or SAP ERP systems.  Let's first discuss the potential documents a supplier will upload to Ariba SLP when they register or update their existing registration. 

  • Quality and other Certificates
  • Tax and Financial Documents
  • Supporting Documents that the buyer wants the supplier to upload
  • Contractual or Risk documents

Attachments in Ariba SLP are not restricted to the above documents it could be any Ariba acceptable format that pass the inbuilt Virus test while uploading on the SAP Business Network for Suppliers (which is the UI for the Supplier when trying to register to a Buyer's SLP) 

Secondly, attachment-related inputs can be collected in the Registration, Modular, and Qualification Questionnaire. The SAP Ariba SLP product team recommends receiving certifications with Validity dates through Modular questionnaires only. 

Lastly, Questionnaire respondents can add attachments to a supplier management questionnaire as a response to any of the following questions:

  • Answer type of Attachment.

  • Answer type of Certificate, where one of the certificate detail fields is an attachment field.

  • Any other answer type, with Participant can add additional comments and attachments set to Yes

In the first two cases, the attachment is a direct answer to the question. In the third case, the attachment is an optional addition to the response and can be added with or without a comment. For more details about the attachment sizes supported refer to the help documentation here.

Our Solution: A Dedicated Integration Package for Attachments

Given the context above, customers seeking attachment integration typically fall into two categories:

  1. Existing Users: Customers already live with the standard SAP Ariba SLP integration (via SAP Integration Suite, Managed Gateway for Spend and Business Network/CIG).

  2. New Implementations: Customers planning or currently implementing the standard SAP SLP-MDG/ERP integration through CIG.

Why This Package is Essential

Our integration package is designed to work for both customer groups because it does not disrupt the standard SAP Ariba CIG integration for Supplier Data Integration.

Instead, we leverage SAP Ariba's open APIs and standard SAP MDG APIs, making the package highly consumable, robust, and extensible for future scenarios. We strongly recommend that customers first implement the standard CIG-based integration for core vendor master data integration and then utilize this package to seamlessly supplement it with attachment integration.

Let's now take a look at the architecture at a high level to see how to achieve this.

High-Level Architecture

The integration package, which we have developed and deployed for customers, operates on a continuous polling mechanism:

  1. It checks SAP Ariba SLP at regular intervals for the latest created and changed suppliers.

  2. It identifies suppliers that are Approved and have a Registered status.

  3. Using SAP Ariba Open APIs, it securely transfers the attachments from the questionnaires to the target system (SAP MDG or SAP ERP), which is configurable based on customer requirements.

  4. The package includes the necessary ABAP code to accurately add the attachment to the SAP MDG Change Request or the SAP ERP Business Partner record.

Benefits of deploying this integration package for the Ariba SLP â†’ SAP MDG / SAP ERP BP Attachment Integration would be,

  • Fully automated attachment flow, zero manual intervention
  • Reduced onboarding cycle time, Accelerates Supplier Onboarding
  • Lower administrative overhead for Supplier Management teams in Customers
  • More consistent and complete supplier records, strengthening compliance and Auditability
  • Enhances Data Quality and Governance
  • Supports Multiple Integration Scenarios (Both SAP MDG and SAP ERP systems)

Customers have reported a 40-60% reduction in manual effort during supplier onboarding, based on the volume of attachments they handle. 

If you have any further questions, please leave a comment below or send your inquiries to the email CoE_AI_PlanningSpendExec@global.corp.sap. We will be happy to get back to you.

entry.title: Source-Side Filtering vs. Dynamic Topics &Filtering with SAP Advanced Event Mesh and ASAPIO Addon
entry.content:
As more and more organizations modernize their integration landscapes whether they are SAP or non-SAP eco systems, Event-Driven Architecture (EDA) is becoming an essential approach to achieving real-time, scalable, and loosely coupled data exchange. Traditional master data distributionâ€”often based on scheduled or API-driven replicationâ€”can no longer keep up with the dynamic needs of digital ecosystems that demand instant synchronization across hybrid SAP and non-SAP environments.

By leveraging SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), and ERP event-on for AEM, enterprises can easily shift toward event-based master data distribution to ensure that updates in systems of records are propagated intelligently, only where and when they are needed. This trend not only reduces system load and redundancy but also enables fine-grained control through mechanisms like source-side filtering and dynamic topic filtering within brokers, which together make EDA a cornerstone for next-generation integration strategies.

Three years ago, I shared a blog on the SAP Event Enablement Add-On for SAP Event Mesh. Since then, SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) has rapidly gained growth as an enterprise-grade event broker with the capability to connect applications, data, and devices across diverse landscapes. 

In this blog, I would like to revisit the ASAPIO Add-On, specifically in the context of integration SAP Advanced Event Mesh. While the add-on continues to be powered by ASAPIO technology, its usage patterns and relevance have evolved alongside AEM's growing adoption. Most of the functionalities are similar but with the ability to build custom payloads and to connect to AEM, it unlocks the value of moving data in real-time from large to very large use cases.

@Benedikt_Sprung   has already published an excellent step-by-step guide on setting up and using the add-on with AEM. Instead of duplicating that content, my focus here will be on a key design consideration: the filtering options available with the add-on and AEM and how they can be applied effectively in real-world scenarios. 

 

Why filtering matters?

Typically, Event-driven architectures (EDA) topics define how events are organized. The way we design and manage topics has a profound impact on scalability, governance, and maintainability. 

In the context of SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) with ASAPIO add-on, two patterns come into discussion with event filtering: source-side filtering (on sender SAP applications) and Dynamic Topics & Filtering (within AEM brokers).

This post explores the difference between these two approaches, when to use each, and how AEM enables more intelligent event distribution in enterprise landscapes.

 

Option 1: Source-Side Filtering on Event Producer

Source-Side filtering usually means the producer (event source) decides dynamically at publish time whether an event should be triggered. Often, a filter based on payload data will be applied to the event liberation.

With ASAPIO add-on, you can use a check function module in header attributes to filter on attributes of the Business Object. For example, you can add the Attribute ID to your Header Attribute customizing in event add-on for ERP: BOR_ATTRIBUTE_<BOR Attribute from SWO1>

 

In this case, only the material data with material group 004 will be triggered. The event broker (AEM) will not receive any data outside of material group 004.

Option 2: Dynamic Topics & Filtering on Event Broker

With this option, the producer (event source) decides at publish time which topic an event should be sent to. Often, topic names are built using runtime data (e.g., customer ID, region, product type).

With ASAPIO add-on, you can set up dynamic topics easily with Field Mapping. It helps you define different layers of the topics and make dynamic filtering easier later during consumption.

 

Based on event context, events can be published to different topics into SAP AEM. Consumers then subscribe only to the events they care about. In above example, topics are built dynamically with the Sales Org ID. If a consumer wants all the data of Sales Order update of Org 1000, it can subscribe to topic /UPDATE/V1/JSON/sap-bo-event/ERD100/1000/BUS2032/>.

In this case, all events are still published to the broker but they can be sorted/routef based on the structure of the topics.

 

When to Use Which?

Source Side Filtering typically works well when consumers are highly specialized and fixed. You don't expect new applications to be added in the future. And in the case when broker load and network traffic is a concern, you can use this option to reduce overhead.

In contrast, dynamic topics & filtering helps you operate at enterprise scale (hundreds of apps, regions, business lines). You want to use this option when you want producers to stay simple and consumers to self-serve. with SAP AEM, it can support very large scale use cases. Using this option will help you have better governance and discoverability on events. 

Dynamic topics & filtering is recommended in most of the use cases as it supports better scalability and flexibility in an EDA integration. To support this option, SAP AEM has its Smart Topics feature to organize event topics. The Topic Taxonomy can be described with none+verb+properties. AEM relies on hierarchical topic structures(using  â€œ/â€ separators) to enable dynamic routing, filtering, and fine-tuned subscriptions.

An Example of master data event topics could be:

  • materialmaster / updated / <materialgroup> / <materialtype>
  • materialmaster / created / <materialgroup> / <materialtype>

With a defined structure, subscribers can filter based on dynamic topics that they are interested in:

This allows flexibility of subscription and allows consumers to self-serve as well.

 

Conclusion and key takeaways

While source-side filtering gives flexibility, it often leads to topic sprawl and tighter coupling. With SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh, enterprises can adopt Smart Topics with Dynamic Topics & Filtering â€” a governance-friendly, scalable way to manage events. This approach keeps producers simple and empowers consumers at enterprise scale.

In most of the use cases, master data distribution is a fan-out pattern, in this case Dynamic Topics & Filtering will provide more flexibility to distribute the data based on needs without tight coupling with producers. Below is a reference architecture for a fan-out scenario and with dynamic topic filtering and multiple integration options, you will be able to easily send to the relevant data to consumers.

 

Happy Eventing!!

SAP Integration Suite SAP S/4HANA Event-driven architecture

entry.title: SAP BN4L System Integration for GTT and Freight Collaboration with S/4HANA
entry.content:
SAP BN4L Systems Integration for GTT and Freight Collaboration with S/4HANA

 

 

System Overview and Architecture

SAP Business Network for Logistics (BN4L) is SAP's new collaborative cloud network that empowers logistics businesses to work together more easily than ever before. It consists of the solutions and add-ons below. SAP Business Network for Logistics is a cloud-service solution based on SAP Business Technology Platform.

SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration (FC) improves supply chain efficiency by connecting business partners on a collaborative network that supports jointly managing transactions, exchanging documents, and sharing insights across the value chain. For instance, upon invitation from a shipper, a carrier can onboard onto the network and collaborate with shippers on freight tendering, invoicing, and milestone reporting.

SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace (GTT) is a cloud-based solution that captures, processes, and stores tracking information about business processes, providing real-time transparency of logistics operations. It offers integration functionality with SAP TM and TM in S/4HANA for freight collaboration processes.

SAP Business Network for Logistics material traceability (MT) is a solution that provides end-to-end visibility into a product's journey from raw materials to finished goods. It uses "events" from your own and partner systems to create a complete genealogy of a batch, which helps with compliance, quality control, and more efficient product recalls.

 

Integration Architecture Diagram

 

Technical Integrations for Freight Collaboration & Global Track and Trace:

Enhancement for BN4L's Freight Collaboration Integration with S/4HANA

There are multiple standard interfaces which are used to communicate between BN4L Freight Collaboration and S/4 HANA system.

There are BADIâ€™s being provided for such interfaces to enhance the same.

Some of the BADIâ€™s are mentioned and its associated enhancement spot:

Enhancement Spot: /SCMTMS/TOR_SE_SPOT_TOR

 

For a better understanding hereâ€™s an example for the reference:

Example: If we want to check or update any data related to freight orders coming from BN4L at the time of order confirmation is done.

Solution:

We can implement the BADI /SCMTMS/TOR_SE_TORB_CONF and its following methods:

And we can add the code in Inbound_Processing method to as per requirement.

We can check from the payload under which tag have to check or update the data by getting payload from SRT_MONI and update the data under the relevant fields of the changing parameter of the method namely â€œOUTâ€.

 

 

Enhancement for BN4L's Global Track and Trace Integration with S/4HANA

To achieve this enhancement, we have to enhance standard GTT IDOC Extractor Class in which we can add our custom code.

For a better understanding hereâ€™s an example for the reference:

Example: If we want to send or update the carrier related details at the BN4L system which will provide a better visibility for tracking.

Solution:

We have created a POST-Exit enhancement in the GTT IDOC extractor class ZCL_GTT_STS_EF_PROCESSOR for method ZIF_GTT_STS_EF_PROCESSOR~GET_CONTROL_DATA.

 

In this we have to identify the field of the segment in which we have to update the values.

To get the segment fields we can refer to the class ZCL_GTT_STS_BO_FU_READER and navigate to its attribute section there we will find "CS_MAPPING"

In "CS_MAPPING" we can find all the segment fields which are part of IDOC.

 

There are other standard interfaces which are used to communicate between BN4L Global Track and Trace and S/4 HANA system. BADIâ€™s being provided for such interfaces to enhance the same.

For a better understanding hereâ€™s an example scenario related to the events raised from GTT end.

Example: If we want to update the FO/FB related details in S/4 HANA system whenever a particular event is triggered from GTT system (e.g. CROSS_HANDOVER, HANDOVER etc).

Solution:

We can implement the following BADI and its required methods:

Enhancement Spot: /SCMTMS/SE_SPOT_TPEVT

BADI: /SCMTMS/SE_TPEVTNTF

And we can add the code in ADAPT_DATA_FOR_OMUH method to as per requirement.

We can check from the method signature the changing parameters in which we want to change/update the data based on the custom logic.

entry.title: Restoring Transport Routes After System Refresh â€“ Edit Option Disabled in STMS
entry.content:
Hi Folks,

Greetings! I hope you are all doing well.

During a recent System Refresh activity, I encountered an issue where the Transport Route configuration could not be edited in the Quality system after restoring a backup from the Production system. Since this issue can occur frequently during refresh cycles, I am sharing the root cause, analysis, and step-by-step resolution.

Issue Summary: -

After performing a backup restore from Production to Quality, we executed the standard post-refresh activitiesâ€”one of which includes clearing the existing TMS configuration in the target (Quality) system.

However, once the system came up and I launched STMS, the Edit / Change icon was disabled, preventing me from defining or modifying the transport routes.

 

 

Because the Quality system was refreshed from Production, the original routes and controller information were overwritten or removedâ€”leading to a mismatch between the local TMS configuration and the domain controller.

Root Cause:-

During the system refresh:

  • Transport Management System (TMS) data from Production overwrote the Quality systemâ€™s configuration.
  • As part of cleanup, TMS routes were deleted or became inconsistent.
  • The system lost its connection to the Domain Controller, causing the edit icon in STMS Transport Routes to become unavailable.

Essentially, the Quality system was no longer recognized as part of the transport domain.

Technical Explanation: -

After the refresh:

  • The refreshed system contains production TMSADM keys, not matching the domain controller.
  • Therefore, the system cannot authenticate with the domain controller.
  • As a result, STMS â†’ Transport Routes goes into read-only mode.

To synchronize the system again, we must update the local TMS config with the domain controller.

Solution â€“ Restore TMS Route Using â€œAdjust with Controller: -

Perform the steps in the Quality system:

Step 1: Log in with DDIC user in client 000

This is mandatory because TMS configuration changes can only be done in:

  • Client 000
  • With DDIC or TMSADM authorized users

Step 2: Execute Transaction STMS

The system will try to connect to the domain controller.

STMS T-code

Step 3: Navigate to Transport Routes

Step 4: Adjust Configuration with Domain Controller

Go to: Configuration>Adjust with controller

You will notice the Edit icon is disabled.

Then click on configuration and get option is adjust with controller just see below snap.

 

Click Yes when prompted.

This action forces the Quality system to:

  • Re-import TMS configuration from the Domain Controller
  • Regenerate TMSADM RFC connection
  • Restore the correct system role (Dev â†’ QA â†’ Prod)
  • Load the existing route definitions

Step 5: Save the Transport Route

  • After synchronization, the correct routes appear automatically.
  • Click Save to activate the configuration.

Additional Technical Checks (Optional but Recommended)

  1. Verify RFC connection of TMSADM

         SM59 â†’ ABAP Connections â†’ TMSADM_<SID>_XXX

         Status should be green.

  1. Check Domain Controller system

         In Domain Controller (usually DEV system):
         STMS â†’ Overview â†’ Systems

          Ensure the refreshed system is visible and status is Active.

  1. Check consistency

       Run:

       STMS â†’ System Overview â†’ Extras â†’ Verify Configuration

Conclusion

After a system refresh, you may find the Edit option disabled in STMS due to mismatched TMS configuration. Using â€œAdjust with Controllerâ€ is the correct approach to synchronize the system with the transport domain controller and restore the predefined routes.

This process ensures that:

  • Quality system aligns with the domain controller
  • Routes are restored without manual reconstruction
  • TMS remains consistent and operational

 

Thanks for Reading!

Please feel free to share your thoughts, improvements, or any similar experiences youâ€™ve encountered during system refreshes.

Regards,

Nishant Garg

entry.title: XPRAS Error During MAIN_NEWBAS/XPRAS_AIMMRG in S/4HANA Conversion Execution Phase
entry.content:
During the recent Oracle â†’ HANA system conversion to S/4HANA 2023, we encountered an error in the Execution Phase where SUM stopped with an error at the step MAIN_NEWBAS/XPRAS_AIMMRG.

Overview

During the SUM execution, the process stopped in MAIN_NEWBAS/XPRAS_AIMMRG due to BW-related inconsistencies. The phase could not continue because certain BW InfoObjects were not fully activated before downtime.

 

Analysis

  • While reviewing the error logs (XPRASUPG_NEW.ELG and related BW activation logs), we observed multiple failures related to InfoObject activation.
  • The XPRAS engine failed to merge certain BW objects because the BW content was not in an active state before SUM was started.
  • We validated client settings, checked multiple profiles, reviewed shadow logs, and compared BW content activation status before correlating this with the root cause.
  • Only after detailed log review and cross-checking, it became clear that the system required specific BW preparation activities prior to downtime.

How to Identify

These indicators helped confirm the issue early:

  1. XPRAS error in XPRASUPG_NEW.ELG with BW InfoObject activation entries.
  2. Multiple failed entries referring to missing or inactive InfoObjects.
  3. BW task list not executed before downtime (SAP_BW_SETUP_INITIAL_S4HANA).
  4. Running STC01 or RSDG_IOBJ_ACTIVATE manually showed several inactive objects.
  5. SUM repeating the same activation attempts and stopping again.

This combination confirmed that BW content activation was incomplete prior to the conversion.

Resolution

After confirming the root cause, we performed the below steps to fix the issue:

  1. Implemented the required corrections in Client 000 using a non-DDIC user with SAP_ALL.
  2. Activated the missing BW InfoObjects as per SAP Note 3315495.
  3. Ensured the system was locked again and resumed the SUM execution.
  4. SUM continued successfully without further XPRAS errors.

Workaround (for early detection )

To prevent the issue in the next conversion cycles (QA/DR/Production):

  • Implement SAP Notes 3305016 and 3316148 before executing SUM.
    â€¢ Before downtime, run task list:
    STC01 â†’ SAP_BW_SETUP_INITIAL_S4HANA
  • Optionally run:
    Program RSDG_IOBJ_ACTIVATE to ensure all InfoObjects are active.
  • Validate BW readiness in Sandbox during rehearsal runs.

These actions ensure the BW layer is fully consistent before SUM execution begins.

Regards,
Shubham Mishra

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Foundational SAP Notes for SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
This blog post lists the main SAP Notes and software components for SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA 2025. 
This collection is provided as an aid to those customers installing or upgrading to SAP S/4HANA 2025 Cloud Private edition or SAP S/4HANA 2025 On-Premise.

Information is current for the initial shipment stack (ISS) of SAP S/4HANA 2025.

IMPORTANT: Many customers often ask whether they should wait for FPS1 before starting their SAP S/4HANA 2025 projects. To help clarify this, the SAP S/4HANA Regional Implementation Group (RIG) has published a dedicated blog:
Should you wait until FPS1 is available before implementing or upgrading to SAP S/4HANA 2025?

The blog explains that SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS00 is a mature and stable release, already shipping with the long-term maintenance version SAPUI5 1.136, so customers can confidently begin their implementations from day one without waiting for FPS1.

You can find additional information on the major changes for SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA 2025 in blog posts:

    • SAP User Experience Update: Whatâ€™s New for SAP S/4HANA 2025 (Private Cloud and On-Premise)

You can find additional information on the major changes for SAP Fiori Frontend Server in blog post:

    • SAP Fiori deployment options and SAP Fiori front-end server strategy - UPDATE 2025

IMPORTANT: Especially please note the statements in the above blog post around Strategy and future direction for SAP Fiori front-end server. Especially:

SAP Fiori front-end server 2025 for SAP S/4HANA (SAP FES 2025) :
